Manual - English: Devadatta (lhas sbyin) kills an elephant. Nanda (dga’ bo) catches an elephant by the tail, but loses it.  The Buddha grabs an elephant and throws it far away. This scene should accord with common [understandings]. The Mahayana tradition has it that the Buddha throws an elephant with his big toe, but it is clear in the traditions of History (sngon 'byung) and Vinaya and so forth that Buddha throws an elephant with his hand. Many trees are cut. The trees fall immediately when others cut them down. The trees the Buddha cuts down won't fall for a long time. They only fall when winds blow them. Then, there is the archery contests drawn according to common conceptions. Generally, the Buddha competes in up to five hundred categories of sports, but the traditions of History (sngon 'byung) and Vinaya are silent on the rest of the sport categories, so it is fine for us to leave off here.

Sun of Faith - English: Devadatta started challenging everyone. He fought one boy after another and knocked each one down.
Seeing the Bodhisattva approach the area,
Devadatta lunged towards him so as to strike him.
but was abruptly propelled high up into the air, and, without any injury,
fell back hard onto the ground, landing on his back with his feet skyward.
These facts are described in the Abhiniṣkramaṇa-sūtra.
Shortly thereafter, the Licchavis of the city of Vaishali (Yangs pa can/ Bai sha la) captured an elephant that bore some extremely unusual marks.
Reckoning that a creature so remarkable looking must owe its existence to the power of Shuddhodana's son (whom all saw as destined to become a universal monarch),
the Licchavis decided to offer the elephant to him.
They therefore sent off an elephant driver to deliver the present up to Siddhartha. On reaching Kapilavastu, the mahout drove the elephant to the palace gates and waited for the prince to show up.
Instead, Devadatta arrived on the scene,
and noticing the magnificent animal interrogated the Licchavis' messenger—
who blurted out the whole story.
“What an idiotic idea, giving this elephant to the prince even before he has attained the rank of a universal monarch!” Devadatta fumed, mad with jealousy.
He slapped the beast with the palm of his hand and killed him.

On sighting the massive corpse, Nanda (Dga' bo), the Bodhisattva's half-brother, said to himself: “Well, since Devadatta has let his strength be displayed in broad daylight, I needn't conceal my own.”
Nanda caught hold of the elephant by its tail, dragged it a few paces and flung it by the wayside.
At that point the Bodhisattva appeared near the city gates, wishing to know what had occurred.
Once he learned the circumstances, he also said to himself: “If that's the case, then I needn't hold back.”
With one finger he took hold of the elephant's tail, lifted the beast off the ground and hurled it.
The carcass flew above the seven ramparts, above the seven moats that encircled the city and fell at some hundreds of fathoms,
thus making a wide depression in the ground.
This famous valley, called Elephant Hollow, was commemorated by the construction of a stupa.
The five hundred stalwart youths then went off to the forest [to compete with each other in the martial arts].
They were occupied in chopping down trees with their sabers when the Bodhisattva joined them.
The other boys were hacking at the trunk, one cut to the left, one to the right, and the tree came down.
But the Bodhisattva did not slash at the trunk from the sides.
He cleft it with one horizontal stroke of his sword. This left the tree standing as if nothing had happened to it.
Watching him in action, the other Shakyas thought that since he had not received his training alongside them, he did not know how to fell trees.
They were smirking and whispering among themselves until a light breeze rose.
Picture their bewilderment when they saw that the trees slashed at by the Bodhisattva all came down with one accord and with an earsplitting crack.
Next, the young people chose to hold an archery competition.
. They set up several targets—seven palm trees, seven drums and a boar, all made of metal—
and took aim one after another.
Devadatta's arrow went right through one metal target
and that of Nanda, through two.
Nobody could better that.
Taking a bronze arrow, the Bodhisattva pierced all the targets in a single strike.
The arrow continued to fly far, very far
before getting embedded deep in the ground.
From this hole serpent-spirits made water of a thousand flavors come gushing out.

Oracle-priests predicted that were Prince Siddhartha to refrain from renouncing the worldly life over the next twelve years to come, he would definitely become a universal monarch.
